metadata.title: High performance cement composites with colloidal nano-silica

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
High performance cement composites with colloidal nano-silica
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.07.045 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: hongjiandu@swin.edu.au (H. Du), ceepsd@nus.edu.sg
(S.D. Pang).
Hongjian Du a,⇑, Sze Dai Pang b aDepartment of Civil and Construction Engineering, Swinburne University of Technology, Victoria 3122, Australia bDepartment of Civil and Environmental Engineering, National University of Singapore, 117576 Singapore, Singapore
h i g h l i g h t s
This paper first reports the influence of nano-silica on high strength mortar. Pore system was refined and more disconnected. Compressive strength and transport properties were improved. Drying shrinkage was reduced due to the refined microstructure. The enhancing efficiency was compared in high strength and normal strength mortar.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 January 2019 Received in revised form 16 March 2019 Accepted 6 July 2019
Keywords: Compressive strength Nanotechnology Durability Microstructure Pozzolanic reaction
a b s t r a c t
Recent studies have demonstrated the advantages of using nano-silica in building materials such as concrete due to its nano-filler effect as well as the pozzolanic reaction. However, most of the previous findings are based on normal strength cement composites. In this study, a wide range of properties of high performance cement composites are investigated with addition of colloidal nano-silica (CNS) at dosage of 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5% and 2.0%. Attributed to the pozzolanic reaction of CNS, the microstructures are denser and more homogenous. SEM observation, accelerated hydration rate and reduced Portlandite content verify this beneficial reaction. Hence, the CNS can help produce cement composites with higher mechanical strength and better durability regards to the impermeability to water and chloride ions. Also, it is found that the influence of CNS is more pronounced for composites with lower water-cement ratio at 0.30, in comparison with those at 0.50.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of nanotechnology recently, there has been an increasing awareness of applying nanotechnology in construction and building materials, mainly including characterizing the mechanical behaviors at nanometer scale and using nanoparticles to modify the performances of cement composites. For the later area, some nano-particles have been demonstrated to be able to provide obvious improvement or enhancement in the cement composites with regards to accelerated cement hydration, modified microstructure, better mechanical strength, increased durability and even smart multi-functions [1–3]. Nano-silica is more often studied compared to other nano-particles such as nano-calcium carbonate, nano-titanium dioxide, because of its pozzolanic reaction with calcium hydroxide in pore solution in
cement paste, expressed as SiO2 + Ca(OH)2 + H2O? C-S-H [4–34]. Through this pozzolanic reaction, the Portlandite, a product of cement hydration, can be consumed to form additional calcium silicate hydrates (C-S-H) which contribute to the binding capacity for cementitious system. Attributed to its high surface area, corresponding to fine particle size, the pozzolanic reactivity of nanosilica is superior to traditional micro-silica [12,35]. The above mentioned benefits of nano-silica have been demonstrated previously, based on normal strength cement mortar or concrete with waterto-binder (w/b) ratio between 0.35 and 0.50. Use of nano-silica in high performance cement composites (HPCC) or ultra-high cement composite (UHPC) is still limited so far.
Oertel et al. [23] clarified the difference between different commercial nano-silica during the cement hydration processes, for UHPC with w/c ratio of 0.28. They found that chemically synthesized nano-silica exhibited high reactivity and contributed more to the microstructure densification rather than on cement hydration. In contrast, low reactivity nano-silica produced from high temperature processes would accelerate the cement hydration by
providing more nucleation on the silica surface. Kong et al. [11] investigated the influence of precipitated nano-silica on the microstructure and properties of HPC at w/c ratio of 0.30. The mechanical strength and resistance to calcium leaching and chloride ions penetration are all enhanced, regardless of nano-silica type and dosage. However, the dispersion of nano-silica remains an issue negatively affecting mortar properties since the agglomerations of nano-silica would form weak zones. A similar conclusion was also drawn by Ghafari et al. [26] who used dry powdered nano-silica in UHPC with w/b ratio of 0.16 and maximum sand size of 0.6 mm. Optimum nano-silica content was determined to be 3%, beyond which no further improvement on strength or impermeability could be observed due to the strong agglomerating tendency of silica nano-particles. The same optimum addition of 3% was also obtained by Rong et al. [28], based on UHPC withw/b ratio of 0.20. Wu et al [36] recently reported that 1% nano-silica powder dosage in UHPC could enhance the interfacial bond between fiber and cement matrix while higher dosage might lead to reduced performance. Li [4] presented the strength and microstructure of highvolume fly ash concrete (HFAC) containing 4% powder nano-silica, at w/b ratio of 0.28. Compared with plain HFAC, the compressive strength was improved, particularly at an early age, owing to the accelerated cement hydration caused by nano-silica. However, this statement disagrees with the finding by Kawashima et al [14], in which the strength of HVFC with 5% nano-silica was observed to decrease at later age because the formed pozzolanic products of nano-silica could hinder the hydration of fly ash particles.
From the literature review, it is noted that no comprehensive study has been conducted to evaluate the influence of colloidal nano-silica on various properties of HPCC. Therefore, this paper aims to investigate the properties of HPCC with varying nanosilica dosage. Besides the cement hydration, mechanical strength and drying shrinkage, durability properties including water permeability and chloride ions migration and diffusivity are emphasized in this study. SEM and MIP are both employed to provide evidences for the change in microstructures and pore systems. Also, the influences are also compared with those at a higher w/c ratio of 0.50 at the same nano-silica dosages, respectively. The results can shed light on the potential use of nano-silica in high performance cement-based materials, particularly regarding durability aspects.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: CEM I 52.5 N cement (content of clinker minerals in wt. %: C3S 67.2, C2S 7.3, C3A 6.4, C4AF 9.6) was used in this study. Cement has surface area of 393 m2/kg and median particle size of about 10 mm. Natural sand with a fineness modulus of 2.80 and specific gravity of 2.65 was used as fine aggregates. The maximum sand particle size is 4.75 mm. Colloidal nano-silica (LUDOX TM-40) contains 40% solids and has a density of 1.3 g/mL. The surface area of nano-silica is 140 m2/g, and correspondingly the average particle size is 20 nm. Fig. 1 shows the dispersion and morphology of nano-silica particles in the liquid suspension as-received. Fig. 2 shows the particle size distributions for cement and CNS. Modified naphthalene sulfonate superplasticizer, DARACEM100 (W.R. Grace & Co. -Conn.) was used to maintain the flowability of mortar mix.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mix proportions
sections.text:
Two reference mortar mixes were selected in this study, withw/ c ratio of 0.30 and 0.50, respectively, as shown in Table 1. CNS was added at 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5% and 2.0% by weight of cement to the reference mixes. CNS was first dispersed in the mixing water and stir-
red for 1 min. Sand and cement was dry mixed in Hobart mixer for 2 min before adding CNS-water solution. The amount of superplasticizer was adjusted to maintain the same flowability for each mortar mix. Table 2 lists the dosage of superplasticizer and corresponding flowability for each mortar mixture. After 3 min of mixing, the fresh mixture was poured into steel molds and compacted on a vibration table. All the specimens were demolded after 24 h and cured in saturated lime water until the testing age.

sections.heading: 2.3. Specimens and test methods
sections.text:
For each mortar mixture, fifteen 50 50 50 mm cubes, nine Ø100 50 mm slices, one Ø100 100 mm cylindrical specimen, and three 25 25 285 mm bars were prepared in total. Cube compressive strength was determined according to ASTM C 109 [37], at 1, 3, 7, 28 and 91 days, respectively. At the curing age of both 7 and 28 days, water sorptivity was measured as per ASTM C 1585 [38]. Rapid chloride migration (RCM) test was carried out as per NT Build 492 [39] at the age of 28 days. At the age of 28 days, chloride diffusion coefficient was determined by immersing cylindrical specimen in salt solution (185 g/L) for 49 days in accordance with NT Build 443 [40]. Epoxy was coated on the top and side surfaces of the specimen to ensure the one direction diffusion of chloride ions. For the drying shrinkage, mortar bar specimens were cured for 3 days in lime water and then stored in controlled room (30 C, 65% RH). The length was measured up to 180 days, according to ASTM C 596 [41]. The pore size distribution was also characterized by using MIP instrument (micromeritics AutoPore III) for mortar specimens at the fractured surface after compression test. The samples were cured in a vacuum dessicator at 40 C for 7 days before MIP measurement.
Paste samples were also prepared to investigate the influence of CNS on the hydration rate and the amount of calcium hydroxide at different ages. Mix proportion for paste was the same as mortarwithout sand ingredient. Isothermal calorimetry was performed by using an eight-channel microcalorimeter (TAM AIR). LINSEIS L81-II was used to measure the thermogravimetric (TG) curves for paste samples. Powder sample (105 C oven dried for 18 h and ground to pass 75-mm sieve) was heated from ambient tem-
perature until 1000 C at a rate of 10 C/min, under the environment of flowing nitrogen. The content of calcium hydroxide can be extracted from the TG curve [42], as illustrated in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 3.1. Calorimetric analysis
sections.text:
The influence of CNS on the hydration rate of cement is shown in Fig. 4(a) and (b) for w/c ratio of 0.50 and 0.30, respectively. For higher w/c ratio of 0.50, the hydration rate was continuously increased by higher CNS amount. The time corresponding to the hydration peak was reduced from 9.8 h for plain OPC paste to 8.4 h for paste with 2.0% CNS. It should be noted that no superplasticizer was used for any mix in this series (w/c = 0.50). This hydration acceleration is consistent with previous findings [23,24], as a result of the seeding effect of CNS which provides nucleate site for the formation of C-S-H.
At w/c ratio of 0.30, the reference paste without CNS exhibited an obvious retardation on its hydration in comparison with the reference mix with w/c ratio of 0.50, mainly attributed to the addition of SP which was used to maintain the same flowability. The dormant period is prolonged due to the reduced dissolution rate of Ca2+ from the cement particles and the inhibited ettringite crystallization. However, the addition of CNS, even at a small dosage of 0.5%, could significantly accelerate the cement hydration. Beyond 0.5%, the main hydration peak came first for paste with 1.0% CNS, followed by 1.5% and 2.0% CNS. Also, the peak rate was increased with increasing CNS content until 1.5% while 2.0% CNS paste exhibited a slightly reduced peak rate because of the high amount of superplasticizer. Rong et al. [28] observed a clear reduction on the peak hydration rate at 3% and 5% CNS addition, at w/c ratio of 0.2, in agreement with this finding that high dosage of CNS might delay the cement hydration.

sections.heading: 3.2. Portlandite content
sections.text:
The pozzolanic reaction between CNS and cement hydration products can be reflected by the reduced Portlandite content in paste. The development of Portlandite content in paste containing 0, 1% and 2% CNS is shown in Fig. 5. At w/c ratio of 0.50, Portlandite content in paste keeps decreasing with higher CNS content at each testing age, because of the pozzolanic reaction of CNS which consumes Portlandite even on the first day. This agrees well with the previous finding for plain cement paste [15,28,35] or paste with high volume fly ash [14]. The change in Portlandite content for plain cement paste is less notable after 7 days, implying that the cement hydration has been almost completed. The same trend was also observed for paste with 1% and 2% CNS, which indicates that the pozzolanic reaction of CNS is also complete. Or otherwise, Portlandite content would be lessened by the consumption of CNS.
At w/c ratio of 0.30, the Portlandite content is overall lower than that of paste withw/c ratio 0.50 due to the lower cement hydration
degree. The added CNS could decrease the Portlandite content particularly from 7 days onwards. With longer curing time, Portlandite content drops from 14 days to 28 days for NS incorporated paste, possibly due to the continuous consumption by nano-silica. Yu et al. [27] and Rong et al. [27] both reported a reduction in the Portlandite amount in the UHPC paste. The comparisons are displayed in Fig. 4(c).
XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 6 for the raw cement clinkers and pastes with plain cement and incorporating CNS. With the addition of CNS, peaks corresponding Portlandite were weakened regardless of w/c ratio, in agreement with the TG result. Compared to pastes with w/c ratio of 0.5, HPCC pastes exhibited negligible peaks corresponding to calcium carbonate but higher intensity of peaks corresponding to unhydrated alite. This is because there is no sufficient space for the hydration products to form at this low w/c ratio. It is also noted that the peak intensity change of (0 0 1) crystal face is more obvious than (1 0 0) and (1 0 1) crystal faces of Portlandite. This reveals that the addition of CNS could decrease the orientation of Portlandite crystals, in agreement with a previous study [35].

sections.heading: 3.3. Microstructure
sections.text:
Pore size distribution (PSD) curves of mortar with CNS are displayed in Fig. 7. It is clearly seen that the addition of CNS could reduce the porosity, regardless of w/c ratio. Mortar with lower w/ c ratio generally has lower porosity and smaller pores, indicating a denser and less porous cement matrix. Compared to reference mortar, CNS could shift the curve towards domains of finer pore sizes (that is the left side in Fig. 7), implying that the capillary pores are refined by CNS, as summarized in Table 3. The reduced porosity and pore sizes should be due to the filler effect of silica nano-particles, reducing the voids in the bulk paste and those in interface between paste and aggregates. Meanwhile, the pozzolanic reaction of CNS could turn Portlandite to C-S-H gel, further reducing porosity and refining the pores. A comparison was made with some previous studies, as plotted in Fig. 7(c). Except the only increasing one reported by [29], all the rest available results indicated the same trend, that is the incorporation of CNS could lower the porosity due to its nanofiller and pozzolanic reaction. It is also noticed that some literature found an optimum CNS addition of about 3% [28] or 4% [29], beyond which the porosity would not be further filled. At the same time, previous literature consistently agrees with the refining effect of CNS for the capillary pore systems, despite the inconsistent results on the total porosity, as mentioned earlier.
SEM photos in Fig. 8 show that the microstructures at interfacial transition zone (ITZ) could be obviously modified from porous to more compact and homogeneous. This is attributed to the combined effect of nano-filling effect and pozzolanic reaction of
nano-silica. As a result, large pores could be reduced and refined and at the same time Portlandite was consumed to form secondary C-S-H gels, as displayed in Fig. 8(b). Since ITZ is normally the weakest phase in cement composites, it is expected the mortar with CNS could have higher mechanical strength and better impermeability due to its enhanced ITZ.

sections.heading: 3.4. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Compressive strength of mortar containing varying contents of CNS is shown in Fig. 9. For w/c ratio of 0.50, the addition of CNS can continuously improve the strength, at each age. At the age of 28 days, mortar (w/c ratio of 0.50) strength can increase by 9%, 8%, 10% and 11% for 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5% and 2.0% CNS addition. This strength increment is 5%, 7%, 10% and 9% for mortar with w/c ratio of 0.30. This improvement is a result of densified microstructure of bulk paste and paste at ITZ because of the pozzolanic reaction of CNS. For w/c ratio of 0.30, the same promoting trend in compressive strength can be found up to 1.5% CNS content. The mechanical strength was reduced at 2.0% CNS addition on the first day. This is due to the high amount of SP added and thus the retarded cement hydration, as revealed in the earlier section. From 3 days onwards, the strength of mortar with 2.0% CNS becomes comparable with that of mortar with 1.5% CNS, at each test age.
From the results, the beneficial effect of CNS on the mechanical properties may be even more obvious at higher dosage more than 2%, which is yet determined in this study. Some previous studies found there was an optimal CNS content (for example, 4% as determined by Yu et al. [27]) beyond which the promoting role would be reduced, as a result of less escaped air voids in paste with increased viscosity. Fig. 10 summarizes the available data on the relationship between CNS content and the cement composites strength increase at 28 days. The general trend is that strength is increasing with CNS content, especially at low CNS addition rate. From these sets of data, a regressed parabola has been obtained. This parabola indicates that the optimum addition and highest increase is 7.59% and 26.98%, respectively. These values may not be accurate since there are other governing factors except the CNS content, such as w/b ratio and aggregate volume in composites. Nevertheless, this parabola qualitatively shows the existence of an optimum CNS content, although it varies among different mix proportions, chemical composition of binder and nano-silica properties.

sections.heading: 3.5. Water sorptivity
sections.text:
Sorptivity of mortar was determined at 28 days and displayed in Fig. 11. Initial and secondary sorptivity presents the rate of water sorption at early stage (within first 6 h) and later stage (1 to 10 days), respectively. The initial sorptivity was consistently reduced for mortar with higher dosage of CNS, regardless of w/c ratio. The secondary sorptivity also obviously decreased, except for 2% CNS mortar with w/c ratio of 0.30. Because of the pozzolanic reaction and filling effect of CNS, capillary pore systems are refined and less connected, resulting in a reduced rate for water intake. As mentioned in the previous section, the ITZ thickness could also be reduced and thus the paths for water ingress are partially blocked. This agrees well with previous finding on the reduction efficiency of CNS in water sorptivity [10,19,20,26]. For mortar with w/c ratio of 0.30, its water sorptivity is overall lower than that of mortar with w/c ratio of 0.50 because of the lower porosity and smaller critical pore size, as evidenced by MIP result in Table 3. The influence of CNS on mortar’s water sorptivity (both initial and secondary) is more pronounced for mix with higher w/c ratio. The results in this study are in consistency with a previous study [10] which reveals that CNS is more efficient in controlling the water absorption rate for paste with higher w/c ratio. One possible expla-

sections.heading: 3.6. Chloride migration
sections.text:
The non-steady-state migration coefficient (Dnssm) was obtained from the following formula. Dnssm ¼ 0:0239 273þ Tð ÞLU 2ð Þt xd 0:0238 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 273þ Tð ÞLxd U 2 r" # ð1Þ
in which U is the applied voltage of 20 V; L is the thickness of the specimen of 50 mm; T is the average temperature; t is the test duration of 24 h; and xd is the chloride penetration depth. The chloride migration coefficients for mortar containing different CNS contents are shown in Fig. 12. Mortar with higher w/c ratio exhibits higher chloride migration coefficient, similar to the observation in water
sorptivity. It is obvious that the migration coefficient could be continuously lowered by higher CNS dosage up to 2%, for w/c ratio of both 0.50 and 0.30. At 2% CNS addition, the migration coefficient was reduced by 20% and 45% for mortar with w/c ratio of 0.50 and 0.30, respectively. This improvement in chloride resistance should be the result of better microstructures at the ITZ, as revealed from MIP curves and SEM observations. Reduced porosity and finer critical pore diameter would both contribute to the hindered transport of chloride ions subject to electrical field through the pore system. This observation is consistent with a previous study [15] which found the chloride penetration depth was reduced by 70% and 55% with the addition of 3% and 6% CNS in the mortar (w/c = 0.4), respectively. Similarly, Quercia et al. [18] also found that 3% CNS addition can lower the concrete chloride migration coefficient to 36% and 38%, at 28 and 91 days, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.7. Chloride diffusivity
sections.text:
The chloride content at each depth was determined and shown in Fig. 13. The chloride content at each depth of concrete sample was determined according to BS 1881-124 [39]. The chloride con-
tent distribution along the depth can be described as the Crank’s solution to Fick’s second law as follows.
Cðx; tÞ ¼ C0 1 erf x 2 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffi Dat p
ð2Þ
where C(x,t) is the chloride content at depth x and immersion time t; C0 is the chloride content at the surface; erf is the error function, and Da is the apparent diffusion coefficient. The chloride concentration for reference mortar was higher than those with CNS, particularly for w/c ratio of 0.30. The parameters were determined by bestfitting Eq (2) by NT Build 443 [43], and summarized in Table 4. The best-fitted curve for each mortar mix was also plotted in Fig. 12. Chloride diffusion coefficient was consistently decreased by the addition of CNS. Compared with the reference mortar, the diffusion coefficient can be reduced by 28% and 34% for mortar containing 2% CNS, at w/c ratio of 0.50 and 0.30, respectively. This result agrees well with previous finding by Quercia et al. [18], in which a reduction of 63% on the chloride diffusion coefficient was reported for SCC containing 3.8% CNS. Furthermore, it is noted that the chloride diffusion coefficient was comparable to the migration coefficient results regardless of w/c ratio, despite the driving mechanisms are different for these two tests. This improved impermeability of mortar against chloride ions in terms of migration and diffusion is a result of the more compact ITZ microstructure [44–46]. The pozzolanic reaction and nano-filler effect of CNS densify the paste at ITZ, thus partially blocking the channel for water and chloride and disconnecting the capillary pores.

sections.heading: 3.8. Drying shrinkage
sections.text:
The drying shrinkages of mortars containing varying dosages of CNS are shown in Fig. 14. No clear trend can be noticed for the drying shrinkage of mortar with w/c ratio of 0.50. For mortar with w/c ratio of 0.30, the addition of CNS can reduced the drying shrinkage, particularly at the dosage of 1.5%. Drying shrinkage of mortar with
2.0% CNS increased slightly, but still smaller than that of plain cement mortar. There is only one available literature studying on the drying shrinkage of cement composites with nano-silica [47]. In that study, the paste containing 3% and 5% NS exhibited comparable and less drying shrinkage than the control paste, attributed to the higher stiffness. A recent study [48] also confirms that NS can reduce the drying shrinkage of mortar as a result of the better mechanical property. The results obtained in this study showed the same trend with some previous studies on the silica fume influence on shrinkage of cement composites [49–51]. Due to the pozzolanic reaction and nano-filler effect of CNS, more C-S-H gel would form and microstructure be more compact, leading to a stronger resistance to the deformation caused by the moisture diffusion outwards.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
This study carried out a comprehensive investigation to characterize the influences of CNS on various properties of both normaland high-performance cement mortar. The following conclusions can be reached:
1) CNS can accelerate the rate of cement hydration due to the nucleating effects. This observation is much more pronounced for high performance cement paste (lower w/c ratio) in which superplasticizer used for workability causes prolonged setting. 2) Portlandite content in normal paste is higher than high performance paste because more water is available for cement hydration. CNS reacts with Portlandite in the hydrated paste to form additional C-S-H gel, as evidenced by the reduced Portlandite content in both normal and high performance pastes. 3) CNS can improve compressive strength of both normal and high performance mortar through densifying the pore structures. Transport of both water and chloride ions in normal and high performance mortar are hindered by the addition of CNS, attributed to the more tortuous pathway, lower porosity and smaller pore size as determined from MIP measurement. 4) CNS enhancement on strength and chloride-ion resistance is be more distinct for cement mortar with w/c ratio of 0.30.
Declaration of Competing Interest
None.

metadata.abstractText: Recent studies have demonstrated the advantages of using nano-silica in building materials such as concrete due to its nano-filler effect as well as the pozzolanic reaction. However, most of the previous findings are based on normal strength cement composites. In this study, a wide range of properties of high performance cement composites are investigated with addition of colloidal nano-silica (CNS) at dosage of 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5% and 2.0%. Attributed to the pozzolanic reaction of CNS, the microstructures are denser and more homogenous. SEM observation, accelerated hydration rate and reduced Portlandite content verify this beneficial reaction. Hence, the CNS can help produce cement composites with higher mechanical strength and better durability regards to the impermeability to water and chloride ions. Also, it is found that the influence of CNS is more pronounced for composites with lower water-cement ratio at 0.30, in comparison with those at 0.50. 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
